message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Standard translations all use "virtue" for 德 — reconsider?">
New data for the 德 discussion. The passage 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼 (Dao De Jing Ch. 38) has well-established standard English translations:

**D.C. Lau**: "When the way was lost there was virtue; when virtue was lost there was benevolence; when benevolence was lost there was rectitude; when rectitude was lost there were the rites."

**Wing-tsit Chan**: "When the Way is lost, only then do we have virtue; when virtue is lost, only then do we have humanity; when humanity is lost, only then do we have righteousness; when righteousness is lost, only then do we have propriety."

**James Legge**: "When the Tao was lost, its attributes appeared; when its attributes were lost, benevolence appeared; when benevolence was lost, righteousness appeared; when righteousness was lost, the proprieties appeared."

Every major translator uses "virtue" for 德 in this passage. Our decision was "(constitutive) character" instead.

Given this data — does this change your view? Should we:
A) Keep "(constitutive) character" — our reasoned departure from tradition, acknowledged in TN
B) Use the standard "virtue" for the Laozi block quote specifically (since it IS a quotation of a classical text), then switch to "(constitutive) character" when the author begins their own analysis
C) Something else?

Brief response with your recommendation.
</teammate-message>

input.summary: Option B -- "virtue" in Laozi quote, "character" in author's analysis
input.content:
**Option B.**

The Laozi passage is a *quotation* of a canonical text. Readers who know this passage in English know it with "virtue." Using "(constitutive) character" in the block quote would make the reader think they are reading an unfamiliar text rather than recognizing DDJ Ch. 38. Recognition matters here -- the author's argument gains force precisely because the reader already has the conventional reading in mind and then watches the author dismantle it.

The switch from "virtue" in the block quote to "character" in the author's analysis actually *enacts* the author's philosophical move. The reader sees the familiar "virtue" in the Laozi quote, then watches the author reinterpret 德 as something different -- "character" -- through the phenomenological reversal. The terminological shift mirrors the conceptual shift. A TN at the transition point makes this explicit: "The author's analysis reinterprets 德 not as moral virtue but as constitutive character -- what makes a thing what it is. See glossary."

This also respects the 文言 convention we already established: classical quotations preserve their standard rendering; the author's modern analysis uses our translation decisions.
